description: From Middle English *grapplen (“to seize, lay hold of”), from Old English *græpplian (“to seize”) (compare Old English ġegræppian (“to seize”)), from Proto-Germanic *graipilōną, *grabbalōną (“to seize”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰrebʰ- (“to take, seize, rake”), equivalent to grab +‎ -le.

Cognate with Dutch grabbelen (“to grope, scramble, scrabble”), German grabbeln (“to rummage, grope about”) and grapsen, grapschen (“to seize, grasp, grabble”). Influenced in some senses by grapple (“tool with claws or hooks”, noun) (see below). See further at grasp.

verbs.description: grapple (third-person singular simple present grapples, present participle grappling, simple past and past participle grappled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To seize something and hold it firmly.
(figuratively, with with) To ponder and intensely evaluate a problem; to struggle to deal with.

description: From Middle English *grapple, *graple, from Old French grappil (“a ship's grapple”) (compare Old French grappin (“hook”)), from Old French grape, grappe, crape (“hook”), of Germanic origin, from Frankish *krappō (“hook”), from Proto-Indo-European *grep- (“hook”), *gremb- (“crooked, uneven”), from Proto-Indo-European *ger- (“to turn, bend, twist”). See further at grape. Influenced in some senses by grapple (“seize”, verb) (see above).

definitionGroups.group: A tool with claws or hooks which is used to catch or hold something.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A device consisting of iron claws, attached to the end of a rope, used for grasping and holding an enemy ship prior to boarding; a grappling iron.

verbs.description: grapple (third-person singular simple present grapples, present participle grappling, simple past and past participle grappled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fasten, as with a grapple; (by extension) to fix; to join indissolubly.
examples: c. 1599–1602 (date written),  William Shakespeare,  “The Tragedie of Hamlet, Prince of Denmarke”, in  Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies […] (First Folio), London:  […]  Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, →OCLC, [Act I, scene iii]:Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To climb (whether by means of a grapple and rope, or by hand, etc).
examples: MacAdams didn't look back to see what they were up to, just ran across the flat roof and grappled down the other side of the building.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To use a grapple (for example to attempt to find, hook, and raise a net or cable).
examples: The following days I spent patrolling the river and grappling for nets. On Wednesday , 18th July , left Gananoque at 7 a.m.; patrolled down to Rockport,  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To hook and raise with a grapple.
examples: The place where the cable got jammed and broken at the bottom was two or three miles from where I grappled up the cable the first time. I do not, of course,  know for certain whether rocks with crevices exist.

entries.meaning: (marketing) A combination of grape and apple flavors.
